Reflection

"Based on environmental education and various philosophical concepts, this app invites you to explore your relationship with yourself, others, nature, and society. It aims at creating a deeper connection with the world inside and around you.
Through exercises and introspective questions, you will be challenged to get out of your comfort zone and free yourself from some of the more hindering assumptions of modern life. Focus on the process, there are no “good or bad answers”, it is all about your personal growth.
These exercises involve you to take actions with yourself, others and nature. Therefore, be safe, responsible, and kind with any interaction towards yourself or the outside world! Remember to have fun and to be curious and open-minded!
We humbly hope that this will make at least a slight difference in your life (even for a microsecond!), and that you’ll enjoy being part of the movement towards a more sustainable and compassionate world."
How To Use The App
The functionality of the app is pretty simple. All of the icons below can be clicked on for navigation. Click on each icon to learn more.
Opens up the exercise menu for the selected category. In this case the category is Nature. The star count below the image keeps track of how many exercises you\'ve completed.
Open Exercise Menu Button
Starts the selected exercise. When the exercise is completed the star turns gold. You can also long click the exercise to reset the star.
Start Exercise Button
A basic home button that allows you to access the home menu.
Home Button
The shuffle icon will randomly select and start an exercise for you.
Shuffle Button
The bookmark icon will save the current exercise for later, or load the saved exercise when on the home screen.
Bookmark Button
The info icon will let you know which category and exercise you are currently on.
Info Button
With Self…
Create For the Experience

"\"If you hear a voice within you say 'you cannot paint,' then by all means paint, and that voice will be silenced\"
- Vincent Van Gogh"
Pick an artistic medium you are not comfortable with and just try … Create!
Were you scared at all to start creating? Did you judge yourself? Why or why not?
Did you have a preconception of what is good art? What does creativity mean to you?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Dance, Dance, Dance!

"\"I don't do well with snakes and I can't dance.\"
- Robin Williams"
Be alone. Listen to your favorite songs and dance to them anyway you want!
How comfortable were you about moving your body to the music? What parts of your body did you move the most?
Did you think at all while you were dancing? Did you lose track of time? How long did you dance for?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Dreams Are What We’re Made Of

"\"My dreams were all my own; I accounted for them to nobody; they were my refuge when annoyed - my dearest pleasure when free.\"
- Mary Shelley"
What were your dreams for the future (about what or who you wanted to be) when you were younger? And what are your dreams right now?
How similar or different were your dreams when you were young to ones you have today?
What influenced your dreams when you were younger? What influences your current dreams now?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Defining Yourself

"\"An identity would seem to be arrived at by the way in which the person faces and uses his experience.\"
- James Baldwin"
Write down a list of single words that define you until you can’t easily think of anymore. Don’t overthink it, write whatever comes to your mind.
Could you categorize the words that describe you into: hobbies, values, roles, qualities …
At what point could you no longer describe yourself? What final words did you land on?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Surf Your Vibe

"\"Men do not quit playing because they grow old; they grow old because they quit playing.\"
- Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr."
What is your favorite hobby? Take some time today (or as soon as you can!) to participate in your favorite activity.
What do you like best about your hobby? Try to describe the different aspects of the activity that you enjoy.
Would you like to do it more? What stops you if that’s the case? Could you make the time somewhere?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Your Story

"\"Our stories come from our lives and from the playwright's pen, the mind of the actor, the roles we create, the artistry of life itself and the quest for peace.\"
- Maya Angelou"
Let’s pretend there is a book about your life. How would the cover look? What would the title of the book be? What about the names of the different chapters?
What genre is your story? Drama? Mystery? Romance? Adventure? Tragedy? Comedy?
All good stories have a central conflict that the hero must overcome. What is your central conflict?
How did this exercise influence your connection with yourself? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
With Others...
Difference of Opinions
"Others Exercise 1 Quote Holder"
"Find someone of your entourage that has a different political or social point of view of yours on a specific topic and just listen. Try to understand how they came to their conclusions.
What was your initial internal reaction to their points of view? How did you feel? Was it hard not to immediately try to counter their opinions?
Did you gain any new perspectives on the matter? Could you feel empathy with someone you disagree with?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Handwriting a surprise-letter
"Others Exercise 2 Quote Holder"

Think about someone you appreciate and value a lot. Take the time to hand write a letter to let them know why, and what you appreciate about them. There’s never too much love to share and receive. Stamp your letter, drop it off at the nearest post office, and away it goes!
Did you feel a difference writing a letter by hand rather than email, text, or digital technologies?
What was the recipient\'s reaction to receiving the letter? Did they also find novelty in a handwritten letter?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Different Small Talk
"Others Exercise 3 Quote Holder"

Next time you bump into a stranger or somebody you don’t know very well, (in the street, at your workplace, at the supermarket) switch from the typical “Hi! How are you?” to “Hi! So what was the best thing that happened in your day so far?”
What was the reaction of the person? What was his\her answer? What have you learned about that person?
And what about you? What is the best thing that happened to you today?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Meet your neighbors
"Others Exercise 4 Quote Holder"
Do you know your neighbors? If you know your close neighbors, what about the ones two doors away ? Knock on their door and introduce yourself!
Was it a short conversation or did it lead to something more than you were expecting?
When you see them out and about next time, will you wave and say hello if it feels good to do so?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
The Elders
"Others Exercise 5 Quote Holder"
Go to a retirement house and speak to an elderly person about his/her life. Ask them about their best childhood memories. What adventures did they have in their youth? Middle age?
How was your experience? What were the conversations about?
What is your perception of elderly people in your society? Did that perception change?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Om mani padme hum..
"Others Exercise 6 Quote Holder"
Attend a religious ceremony of a different faith than your own.

"What have your other experiences with spiritual practices been like? How did you feel during this particular ceremony? How was it similar or different to your past experiences? What aspects of the ceremony did you find most enlightening?"
How were your interactions with the community? Was there anyone you felt a special connection with?
How did this exercise influence your connection with others? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
With Nature...
Hug A Tree!
"Nature Quote One"

"Find the most inspiring tree around your area, and give it a big hug.
While you’re there take a long breath, and thank that tree for the air you are breathing."
Was it your first experience of hugging a tree? How did you feel?
How do you feel about doing this exercise in public?
How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Walk Solo in Nature
"\"The clearest way into the Universe is through a forest wilderness.\" - John Muir"
Go in nature by yourself with no predetermined route (or very minimal one) or length of time.
What was the most exciting thing that happened during that walk?
Were you thinking a lot or not at all? What was in your head?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Nature as a Child
"\"And this, our life, exempt from public haunt, finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, sermons in stones, and good in everything.\" -William Shakespeare"
Try to remember a memory from your childhood that you felt particularly connected with nature. Where was it? Who were with you? What were you doing?
What was the importance of nature during your childhood?
How did this memory or that particular place shape the relationship that you now have with nature?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Do the Earth a Favor!
"Society Exercise 4 Quote Holder"
Walk around your local park or neighborhood and pick up a single piece of trash (or more!) off the ground. Make sure it finds its way to the proper bin! (Remember to compost or recycle if you can.)
Did you notice a lot (or very little) trash where you were walking? What was your initial reaction to the presence of or lack of trash in your immediate surroundings?
How did you feel carrying around someone else’s trash? When it made it to the bin, what was the first feeling that you had?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
The Elements
"Nature Exercise 5 Quote Holder"

Connect mindfully with the four elements using all your senses. The four elements are Earth, Water, Fire and Air. For example, silence your thoughts, and stare at a lit candle, feel the soil with your bare feet, listen to the wind, and smell the ocean.
Which element did you feel the most connected to? Why?
Which sense did you naturally use the most to connect with each element?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Adopt a Pet Plant!
"Nature Exercise 6 Quote Holder"

Find a small plant that is seeding in a park, or in the woods. Gently up root it, and grab some of the soil that it was growing in. Bring it home, put it into a cup or jar, try to identify the species and its basic needs, and see what happens! You now have a new friend!
Why did you choose this plant? What attracted you to that particular plant?
Do you feel any emotional connection with the plant now that it’s home? Did you give it a name?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
With Society...
Disconnect and Unplug
"Society Exercise 1 Quote Holder"
Try to spend just one day (safely!) without your phone. Bonus points if you are actually still in the city, and not in the woods somewhere.
What was your initial reaction? Did you feel stress? Freedom?
When you got back on the grid, what was it like to use your device again?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
The Role of Money
"Society Exercise 2 Quote Holder"
Think of your relationship with money. Focus on your feelings around it, and your initial emotional reaction to your current financial situation.
What is more important to you than money? What would you not give up for any price in the world?
What would you consider “enough”? How big would your bank account have to be that when you see it, you feel safe and free to take opportunities?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Represent Local
"Society Exercise 3 Quote Holder"

"Local and state governments often have a much bigger effect on your life than federal. Attend a local city council meeting, or watch a session of your state congress. Attempt to meet your city council or state government representative. Is there any important local issue you could talk with them about?"
What issues did they discuss? Was there anything about the process that stood out to you?
Did you like your representative? How could you work with them to address the issues you feel concerned about?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Kindness on the Street
"Society Exercise 4 Quote Holder"
Give a person in need some change or food. Ask them their name, and wish them a good day.
What was their reaction? Did their demeanor change once you asked for their name?
How did you feel after the interaction was over? Was there a sense of doing some good?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Every Bit Counts
"Society Exercise 5 Quote Holder"

Sign up to make a small monthly donation (about the cost of a lunch, whatever you can afford) to a charity that advocates for a cause that you support. Any cause will do! A monthly donation makes you a real member of these organizations.
How do you feel about giving to a cause on a regular basis?
Do you think you’ll participate or become more involved with the issue over time?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Do Good Works
"\"What is the essence of life? To serve others and to do good.\" -Aristotle"
A tried and true classic to feel good and meet great people! Find a cause and organization you care about, and volunteer for a day. Even if it’s just once, you certainly won’t forget the experience.
Where did you choose to volunteer? What was the work like?
Did you build good relationships? Did you feel connected with the other volunteers? Your community as a whole?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
